Beep-Beep; Honk-Honk; and Whitehead Hall
The feeling was, way back when, when your editors
were but abstractions in some nether-nether land, that
some four-wheeled monstrosities that went "putt-putt"
and "beep", would never replace the horse. They have.
They come, like women, in all sizes, shapes, and colors.
Nowadays they go "brrroom" and "honk", and have a
nasty habit of killing people. But we, at Hopkins, won't
bother with that side of the story. Around here they
collect like flies on rahcid meat, and the gripe of those
who sit behind the wheel, and assistant plant manager
Joseph Geiger in particular, is that there are just too
many of them.
Back in 1953 the campus had parking facilities for
576 automobiles, and a registration of 2094 cars. This
was not a healthy situation. All sorts of little people
met in various smoked-filled rooms, and emerged with
all sorts of little plans and large aspirations which would
ease the parking problem. Today 815 parking spaces
serve an automobile registration.of 7,678. Without bothering to unsheath a sliderule we can say, without fear of
contradiction, that if the 1953 problem was unhealthy the
present one is tubercular.
The parking commission and the administration met
recently, and decided that the installation of parking
meters on the Homewood lots, as a move to discourage
unnecessary parking, might be feasible. We feel that
this plan reaks far worse than the auto dilemma itself.
First of all, don't the powers that be realize that the
undergraduate pocket is not a horn of plenty? Secondly,
when is parking on the Hopkins cdmpus by a member of
the Hopkins community unnecessary? Thirdly, isn't it
the right of any professor or student of this university
to park his car on the grounds of HIS university without
being taxed for the "privilege"?
We see no remedy for this dilemma which is currently
plaguing campuses the country round. We ask that if
the administration can dig up no answer which does not
dig into an individual's pocket that it let the situation
'stand, as problematic as it- is, until the helicopter age, or
until a rebirth of the era of the walking stick and the
one-horse shay.

On Rioting
Although Spirit is desirable and should be encouraged, the "spirit" displayed Wednesday evening by half
of the dormitory is clearly unacceptable to society and
should be regarded as such.
The swift action of the Baltimore police in this riot
and their avowed intention to deal even more harshly
with Any future outbreaks should make it apparent to
any prudent man that Hopkins riots should become as
extinct as the Dodo.
In the last two riots, a total of ten students have
been arrested and booked. In most cases innocent bystanders have been the victims, too secure in the feeling
that the police won't bother them because they are just
watching. Counting on the continued leniency of the
judge in dismissing charges does not appear to be a safe
gamble in light of feeling of law enforcement officials
that these outbreaks have to cease.
Although the actions of the police were far from
exemplary (beating unresisting student viciously with
nightstick, and using foul language), conviction of a
policeman of conduct unbecoming td an officer and assault
in a riot situation is next to impossible.
Instead of leaving the campus and molesting citizens
of the community, it is suggested that this 'spirit" be
turned into channels of true Spirit, such as support and
participation in Hopkins activities. This is a time when
discretion is the better part of valor.

The feeling was, way back when, when your editors
were but abstractions in some nether-nether land, that
some four-wheeled monstrosities that went "putt-putt"
and "beep", would never replace the horse. They have.
They come, like women, in all sizes, shapes, and colors.
Nowadays they go "brrroom" and "honk", and have a
nasty habit of killing people. But we, at Hopkins, won't
bother with that side of the story. Around here they
collect like flies on rahcid meat, and the gripe of those
who sit behind the wheel, and assistant plant manager
Joseph Geiger in particular, is that there are just too
many of them.
Back in 1953 the campus had parking facilities for
576 automobiles, and a registration of 2094 cars. This
was not a healthy situation. All sorts of little people
met in various smoked-filled rooms, and emerged with
all sorts of little plans and large aspirations which would
ease the parking problem. Today 815 parking spaces
serve an automobile registration.of 7,678. Without bothering to unsheath a sliderule we can say, without fear of
contradiction, that if the 1953 problem was unhealthy the
present one is tubercular.
The parking commission and the administration met
recently, and decided that the installation of parking
meters on the Homewood lots, as a move to discourage
unnecessary parking, might be feasible. We feel that
this plan reaks far worse than the auto dilemma itself.
First of all, don't the powers that be realize that the
undergraduate pocket is not a horn of plenty? Secondly,
when is parking on the Hopkins cdmpus by a member of
the Hopkins community unnecessary? Thirdly, isn't it
the right of any professor or student of this university
to park his car on the grounds of HIS university without
being taxed for the "privilege"?
We see no remedy for this dilemma which is currently
plaguing campuses the country round. We ask that if
the administration can dig up no answer which does not
dig into an individual's pocket that it let the situation
'stand, as problematic as it- is, until the helicopter age, or
until a rebirth of the era of the walking stick and the
one-horse shay.

On Rioting
Although Spirit is desirable and should be encouraged, the "spirit" displayed Wednesday evening by half
of the dormitory is clearly unacceptable to society and
should be regarded as such.
The swift action of the Baltimore police in this riot
and their avowed intention to deal even more harshly
with Any future outbreaks should make it apparent to
any prudent man that Hopkins riots should become as
extinct as the Dodo.
In the last two riots, a total of ten students have
been arrested and booked. In most cases innocent bystanders have been the victims, too secure in the feeling
that the police won't bother them because they are just
watching. Counting on the continued leniency of the
judge in dismissing charges does not appear to be a safe
gamble in light of feeling of law enforcement officials
that these outbreaks have to cease.
Although the actions of the police were far from
exemplary (beating unresisting student viciously with
nightstick, and using foul language), conviction of a
policeman of conduct unbecoming td an officer and assault
in a riot situation is next to impossible.
Instead of leaving the campus and molesting citizens
of the community, it is suggested that this 'spirit" be
turned into channels of true Spirit, such as support and
participation in Hopkins activities. This is a time when
discretion is the better part of valor.

tentatively call photosynthetic
pyridine nucleotide reductase, is
necessary for the transfer of
hydrogen to an important biochemical substance known as
diphosphopyridine nucleotide, or
DPN. This compound which receives the hydrogen atoms is
widespread in nature and contains one of the vitamins called niacin .in its chemical structure.
